body:
@avandeursen BTW I think @signed already had some ideas about a custom Cucumber engine.

The unique IDs of the `TestIdentifier` are used by our `RunListenerAdapter` implementation when the Java class name cannot be determined. We could instead fallback to the parent's display name.

Thanks!

The `RunListenerAdapter` code you are talking about is here I think:

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/r5.0.0-M3/junit-platform-surefire-provider/src/main/java/org/junit/platform/surefire/provider/RunListenerAdapter.java#L89

At that program point, the `testIdentifier` can indeed be used to get the `parentId()`, which is quite similar to the uniqueId of the testIdentifier itself (i.e., both are of the form `[engine:junit-vintage]/[runner:nl.tudelft.cucumber64.CucumberTest]/[test:rO0ABXNyAB9naGV....`)

And how can the parentId be turned into a displayName at that program point?

`RunListenerAdapter` needs to implement `testPlanExecutionStarted()` and store a reference to the current `TestPlan`. It can then use `TestPlan.getParent()` to get the parent `TestIdentifier` of the test.
Ok, thanks. I will look into this.

I have not spend much thought about the report format yet.
Currently my [implementation][junit-cucumber-engine] produces the following report when running your example (no vintage or jupiter engine present on the surefire classpath):
````
<testcase name="Given I have chosen to sign up" classname="nl.tudelft.cucumber64.FeatureSteps" time="0.125"/>
<testcase name="When I sign up with valid details" classname="nl.tudelft.cucumber64.FeatureSteps" time="0"/>
<testcase name="Then I should receive a confirmation email" classname="nl.tudelft.cucumber64.FeatureSteps" time="0"/>
<testcase name="And I should see a personalized greeting message" classname="nl.tudelft.cucumber64.FeatureSteps" time="0"/>
````

I guess the classname is derived from the *MethodSource* I attached to the TestDescriptor.
But no clue where this happens within junit. For navigation in the IDE I'd like to keep the method source in the TestDescriptor.

Is there some way for the engine to influence how the report is generated?

[junit-cucumber-engine]: https://github.com/signed/junit-cucumber-engine

Thanks @signed. I'll have a look at your implementation and your question.

Almost done with the change suggested by @marcphilipp in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/616#issuecomment-269645324 -- pull request will follow shortly.

issue.title: Use parent name in Surefire reporting if class source is missing

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

In surefire reporting, when a test identifier has no class source attached to it, use the display name in the parent as source.

This fixes #616 (which used unique-ids of current test instead of display name of parent)

## Test cases

Contains a new test case for the sourceless case.

Furthermore, a selection of the test cases for checking that certain events fired now also check that the events come with proper class name, method name, and trace writer, if appropriate.

Some common setup code was refactored to the BeforeEach-annotated method.

## Refactorings

Extracted the (somewhat duplicated) code for retrieving a class name from a test identifier into a dedicated method.

## Additional Change

The source-less case covered in this change is now reported using a regular "SimpleReportEntry" -- it used to be reported as an "ignored" entry, which seems incorrect as it is called from the 'executionStarted' method.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.

body:
> I guess the classname is derived from the `MethodSource` I attached to the TestDescriptor.

Indeed! That made me realize that it's actually wrong to derive it that way, e.g. in the following case.

### AbstractTestClass.java
```java
package com.example.project;

import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

class AbstractTestClass {
    @Test
    void test() {
    }
}
```

### Sub1Tests.java
```java
package com.example.project;

class Sub1Tests extends AbstractTestClass {
}
```

### Sub2Tests.java
```java
package com.example.project;

class Sub2Tests extends AbstractTestClass {
}
```

In this case the Surefire reports will look like this:

### TEST-com.example.project.Sub1Tests.xml
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuite xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="https://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/xsd/surefire-test-report.xsd" name="com.example.project.Sub1Tests" time="0.03" tests="1" errors="0" skipped="0" failures="0">
  <properties>
    ...
  </properties>
  <testcase name="test" classname="com.example.project.AbstractTestClass" time="0.005"/>
</testsuite>
```

### TEST-com.example.project.Sub2Tests.xml
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuite xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="https://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/xsd/surefire-test-report.xsd" name="com.example.project.Sub2Tests" time="0.03" tests="1" errors="0" skipped="0" failures="0">
  <properties>
    ...
  </properties>
  <testcase name="test" classname="com.example.project.AbstractTestClass" time="0.005"/>
</testsuite>
```

In both cases, the `classname` is derived from the `MethodSource` which _correctly_ points to the source location of the test case. However, `classname` should be `com.example.project.Sub1Tests` and `com.example.project.Sub2Tests`, respectively.

> Is there some way for the engine to influence how the report is generated?

I think that would be a good way out of this dilemma for this "legacy" XML report. Ultimately, we need a new reporting format (see #373).

@junit-team/junit-lambda What do you think about adding a way for a `TestIdentifier` to specify `classname` and `methodname`? We could make it optional and fallback to using display names.

> @junit-team/junit-lambda What do you think about adding a way for a `TestIdentifier` to specify `classname` and `methodname`? We could make it optional and fallback to using display names.

As long as its optional (i.e., has a _default_ implementation) and well documented, I think it would be OK to introduce those.
